answer.body:
TB is caused by a type of bacteria called Mycobacterium tuberculosis. TB usually affects the lungs, but can also affect other parts of the body. There are 2 forms of TB – active TB disease or latent TB infection.

A person with active TB disease in the lungs is infectious (i.e. can spread the disease to others), and will exhibit specific TB symptoms. A person with latent TB infection does not develop symptoms (e.g. cough) and does not spread TB to others.

The TB bacteria remain inactive in the body. About 5% of persons with latent TB infection may develop active TB disease in the first two years after being infected. For the rest, only 5% may develop active TB disease during the rest of their lifetime.

A person with active TB disease should be treated immediately. The decision to treat latent TB infection is made on a case by case basis.

questionListItems.title: What are the symptoms of active tuberculosis (TB) disease?

answer.body:
Symptoms of active TB disease include:

• Persistent cough that lasts 3 weeks or longer

• Low-grade fever

• Night sweats

• Fatigue

• Weight loss

• Chest pain

questionListItems.title: How is latent tuberculosis (TB) treated? How much does it cost?

answer.body:
Treatment of latent TB infection, when necessary, requires the patient to take an anti-TB drug, Rifampicin for 4 months or Isoniazid, for 6 months.
This will prevent the patient from developing active TB in the future. This is also known as “preventive treatment”.
If you are found to have latent TB infection following contact screening, you may be offered preventive treatment, which will be evaluated monthly by medical professionals at TB Contact Clinic (i.e. treatment progress, side effects and adjustment to medication dosage).
Medication to treat latent TB infection identified through contact screening will be provided free of charge at TB Contact Clinic.

TB is typically spread through prolonged exposure (days to weeks, rather than minutes to hours) to an individual with active TB disease.

When a patient with active TB disease coughs, TB bacteria is released into the air and may be inhaled by those around – prolonged exposure can result in acquiring TB infection.

A person cannot get TB from sharing cups, eating utensils, and food. TB is also not spread through shaking someone’s hand, kissing, or touching bed linens or toilet seats.

questionListItems.title: If there is a case of active tuberculosis (TB) disease in my workplace, is there a need to close the workplace? Will there be continued spread of TB?

answer.body:
Once an individual is diagnosed with active TB disease, treatment is started immediately. He/She will be placed on medical leave during the initial period of treatment, until he/she is no longer infectious.
Exposure to TB would have been in the period before active TB disease was diagnosed and treatment started for the patient.
As there is no further risk of the TB bacteria spreading to other people in the workplace, there is no need to close the workplace, as long as the patient with active TB disease adheres to Directly Observed Therapy (DOT) treatment regularly.

questionListItems.title: What does it mean if I am diagnosed with latent tuberculosis (TB) infection after contact screening? Did I get it from the index case?

answer.body:
The latent TB infection could have been acquired from the index, or from other exposure. Latent TB is not uncommon in Singapore, especially in older persons who may have acquired it in their youth when TB rates in the country were very high.
At the national level, it is estimated that about 1 in 10 Singaporeans have latent TB. This is based on local research which estimated latent TB rates between those aged 18 years to 79 years to be from 2% to about 30%.
While the latent TB rate among those aged below 18 is not available, the latent TB rate is expected to be low in this age group.

questionListItems.title: What should I do if my tuberculosis (TB) screening results are positive?

answer.body: A positive blood test result means that you were infected with TB, but does not indicate as to when the infection occurred, ie. it does not necessarily mean that you were infected by the TB case in your workplace. If you have a positive blood test or an abnormal chest X-ray, appropriate measures will be taken on your follow up visit.

questionListItems.title: What tests are conducted for tuberculosis (TB) screening?

answer.body:
For those who are identified to be at risk of TB infection, the following screening tests will be conducted to detect if an individual has been infected with TB (this could be latent TB or active TB disease).

During TB screening, a blood test is administered, and a Chest X-Ray taken only if necessary as determined by the doctor. In addition, a repeat blood test will be performed 8 weeks after last possible exposure.

This is because if there had been infection with TB, the body may take up to 8 weeks to react and for the test to return positive. This is also known as the test's 'window period'.

questionListItems.title: What is the tuberculosis (TB) screening process?

answer.body:
TB is typically spread through prolonged exposure to an infectious individual, and not all individuals who are exposed to an infectious individual get TB. 
The TBCU will assess and identify persons who are at risk, and conduct the necessary screening tests for these groups of people, so as to properly manage them.

questionListItems.title: What is done when a person is established to have active tuberculosis (TB) disease?

answer.body:
The National TB Programme (NTBP) implements a set of protocols based on well-established internationally-accepted recommendations (e.g. from World Health Organisation) to manage the spread of TB in the community. 
This includes assessment and identification of individuals who are at risk of TB infection, TB screening for those identified, and where necessary, monitoring and/or treatment of individuals.

questionListItems.title: How is active tuberculosis (TB) disease treated? How much does it cost?

answer.body:
Treatment for active TB disease usually involves a combination of several different drugs, taken for 6 to 9 months. More than 95% of patients are cured if they follow the treatment regimen (i.e. take all the medications in a timely manner, as prescribed by the doctors).
A small proportion of patients with active TB disease may require more intensive and longer treatment if they have bacteria that is resistant to first-line treatment. Treatment will be closely monitored by medical professionals to check on treatment progress and any side effects.
TB treatment at the Tuberculosis Control Unit (TBCU) is heavily subsidised for Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents.
